author: TOI Lifestyle Desk
title: ‚ÄãBreast Cancer Symptoms: 5 symptoms women can catch early if they stay alert‚Äã
text:
When it comes to breast cancer, catching those signals early could literally save your life. Yet, many women shrug off or miss early signs because they don‚Äôt seem like a big deal at first. This isn‚Äôt a lecture. It‚Äôs more like a heart-to-heart with your bestie who‚Äôs telling you, ‚ÄúHey, maybe check that out.‚Äù Because while awareness campaigns scream about monthly self-exams, pink ribbons, and mammograms (all important, by the way), what we don‚Äôt talk about enough are the sneaky, weird, not-so-obvious symptoms that women spot way too late.
Let‚Äôs talk about 5 breast cancer symptoms you can actually catch early‚Äîif you‚Äôre just a little more tuned in to your body.
We tend to blame everything on bras, sweat, or hormones. Your nipple itches? ‚ÄúMust be the detergent.‚Äù There‚Äôs a rash? ‚ÄúProbably just eczema.‚Äù It‚Äôs leaking? ‚ÄúWait, what?‚Äù Exactly.
Early breast cancer can mess with your nipples in subtle ways. A sudden change in shape or position; your nipple starts turning inward when it never did before? That‚Äôs not just age. Crusting, scaling, or persistent rash; especially if it‚Äôs just one nipple and refuses to go away with creams. Unexplained discharge; and we‚Äôre not talking post-pregnancy leaks here. If there‚Äôs clear or bloody fluid and you‚Äôre not lactating, that‚Äôs a big deal. It‚Äôs so easy to chalk these off as nothing, but don‚Äôt. Your nipples are like tiny messengers. Don‚Äôt silence them with excuses.
Everyone‚Äôs obsessed with finding a lump‚Äîand yes, that‚Äôs a classic sign. But the truth is, many breast cancers don‚Äôt start as obvious, round, hard bumps.
Sometimes, it‚Äôs more like a thickened area you only notice while showering, a part of your breast that feels denser or firmer than the rest, something that wasn‚Äôt there before but isn‚Äôt exactly a ‚Äúlump.‚Äù Here‚Äôs a little truth bomb: women with dense breasts (which is super common, especially in younger women) already have tissue that feels lumpy or ropey. So, catching a new irregularity requires some familiarity. You‚Äôve got to know your own terrain. This is where self-checks come in‚Äîbut with a twist.
Don‚Äôt poke and prod once a month like it‚Äôs a chore. Just get used to how your boobs normally feel. That way, if something changes, your hands will catch it before it turns into something bigger.
This one‚Äôs straight out of the ‚Äúwait, what?‚Äù category. One of the more alarming early signs is skin dimpling, especially if it starts to resemble the surface of an orange. Doctors call it ‚Äúpeau d‚Äôorange,‚Äù and it‚Äôs usually caused by something blocking the lymphatic drainage in your breast‚Äîoften a tumor.
This isn‚Äôt a surface-level skin issue like a pimple or heat rash. You‚Äôll notice tiny pits or bumps that make your skin look bumpy or stretched, swelling around that area and maybe a little redness or warmth. It‚Äôs often painless, and that‚Äôs the trap. No pain = no action. But if your breast starts resembling fruit, it‚Äôs time to get it checked. Skin is the largest organ, and when it starts changing shape or texture, it‚Äôs usually reacting to something deeper beneath the surface.
We‚Äôve all been there. Your boobs feel sore, tender, achy‚Äîclassic signs your period‚Äôs about to show up. But what happens when that ache lingers? Or it shows up in just one breast? Or it hits you out of cycle?
Breast pain (also called mastalgia) isn‚Äôt always cancer. In fact, it rarely is. But here‚Äôs where it gets tricky: when breast cancer does cause pain, it‚Äôs usually localized to one specific spot, sharp or burning instead of dull and achy and not tied to your period. Most people don‚Äôt associate cancer with pain, but that‚Äôs a myth. Some women report ongoing discomfort in one breast months before diagnosis‚Äîpain that was dismissed as ‚Äúnothing.‚Äù If it sticks around and keeps nagging you, especially if it‚Äôs new or focused in one area, trust your gut and talk to your doc.
Here‚Äôs something most people don‚Äôt realize: your breast tissue extends all the way up into your armpit, and there are loads of lymph nodes there. If something‚Äôs going wrong in your breast, your armpit might be the first place to show signs.
Keep an eye out for swelling or puffiness under your arm, a lump near your armpit or collarbone and a weird heaviness or ‚Äúfull‚Äù feeling on one side. The lymphatic system is like your body‚Äôs drainage system. When it gets blocked or affected‚Äîsay, by cancer cells‚Äîthings start backing up. Early breast cancer might sneak into the lymph nodes before it shows up clearly in the breast itself. So, if your armpit suddenly feels tender or ‚Äúoff,‚Äù don‚Äôt ignore it.
Life is chaotic. Most of us are juggling jobs, families, relationships, and daily survival. Who has time to obsess over every tiny change in their body? But here‚Äôs the thing: early breast cancer doesn‚Äôt always come with drama. There‚Äôs no dramatic lump or sudden sickness. It‚Äôs subtle. Sneaky. Almost polite.
That‚Äôs why women catch it late‚Äînot because they‚Äôre careless, but because the early signs look like stuff we deal with all the time. A rash, a bit of swelling, mild pain. Nothing screams ‚Äúcancer‚Äù right away.
And yet, early detection is the single most powerful tool we have. Breast cancer found early has a five-year survival rate of over 90%. That‚Äôs not just a number‚Äîthat‚Äôs more time with your family, more birthdays, more life.
Here‚Äôs your no-nonsense plan:
Know your boobs like your favorite playlist. You don‚Äôt need a calendar reminder or a checklist. Just check in regularly‚Äîwhile showering, dressing, lying in bed. Learn what‚Äôs normal for you.
Don‚Äôt Google. Talk to your doctor. If something feels weird, resist the urge to consult Dr. Internet. Book that appointment. Even if it‚Äôs nothing, peace of mind is priceless.
Push for tests if you‚Äôre uneasy. Sometimes, symptoms are dismissed‚Äîespecially if you're young or don‚Äôt have a family history. Advocate for yourself. If you feel something‚Äôs off, push for a scan, a second opinion, whatever it takes.
Pay attention to patterns. Is that nipple rash sticking around for more than two weeks? Is that pain getting worse, not better? Patterns help you connect dots that a one-time event might not.
Talk about it. Mention it to your sister, your best friend, your group chat. Women talking about breast changes openly can save lives. You never know who might read your story and realize they‚Äôve been ignoring the same thing.
You don‚Äôt need to be paranoid. You don‚Äôt need to turn every itch into an emergency. But you do need to listen to your body. And when it whispers, don‚Äôt wait for it to scream. Because early breast cancer isn‚Äôt invisible. It‚Äôs just really good at pretending to be something else. And you? You‚Äôre smarter than that. You‚Äôre paying attention now. So here‚Äôs to being breast-aware‚Äînot because we live in fear, but because we care too much not to notice.

author: Syeda Uzma
title: Doctor Slump Episode 14 Recap: Jeong Woo Decides To Propose
text:
JTBC‚Äôs latest rom-com, Doctor Slump, is about to feature a major milestone in Jeong Woo and Ha Neul‚Äôs wholesome relationship. The story centers on Yeo Jeong Woo played by Park Hyung Sik, and Nam Ha Neul, played by Park Shin Hye. Back in school, Yeo Jeong Woo was always the top student and went to the best medical school in the country.
Now, he‚Äôs a famous plastic surgeon with a smooth life, but a strange medical accident shakes things up. That‚Äôs when he meets Nam Ha Neul, an old rival, at his lowest point. Ha Neul works as an anesthesiologist. Growing up, everyone thought she was super smart, and she worked hard to become a doctor.
Her life is just work and studying, leaving no time for fun. One day, she realizes she‚Äôs not happy and wants a change. That‚Äôs when she meets Jeong Woo during a tough time, and they comfort each other, leading to a romantic relationship.
Ha Neul‚Äôs career takes a new turn (Credits: JTBC) Doctor Slump Episode 14 Recap After Kyung-min‚Äôs passing, Jeong-woo and Ha-neul try to return to their regular lives. Ha-neul faces a tough decision when offered a job as an assistant professor at her old hospital, while Jeong-woo struggles with his feelings towards Kyung-min.
They join Ha-neul‚Äôs family on a trip to Busan, where Jeong-woo learns they‚Äôre visiting her father‚Äôs grave. Feeling uncertain, he keeps his distance until he sees the family reminiscing about him with joy, prompting him to confide in Wol-seon about his mixed emotions.
Wol-seon advises Jeong-woo to take his time forgiving himself, leading to a heartfelt moment of solace. Meanwhile, Ha-neul gains clarity about her career path with Tae-seon‚Äôs encouragement, and she shares the news with Jeong-woo, who supports her enthusiastically.
As they embark on a new journey together, Jeong-woo decides to take the next step in their relationship by buying a ring to propose to Ha-neul, marking a hopeful beginning for their future.
Jeong Woo decides to Propose (Credits: JTBC) Doctor Slump Episode 15 Spoilers In the next episode, Jeong-woo deals with his feelings about Kyung-min‚Äôs death, finding solace and guidance from Wol-seon. Meanwhile, Ha-neul considers a career opportunity with Tae-seon‚Äôs encouragement. Their relationship takes a significant step forward as Jeong-woo suddenly surprises Ha-neul with a possible proposal.

author: Matt Wreden
title: San Jose man pleads guilty to setting multiple fires behind firefighters responding to Dixie Fire | News | actionnewsnow.com
text: SACRAMENTO, Calif. - A San Jose man on Thursday plead guilty to three counts of arson on federal property, U.S. Attorney Phillip A. Talbert announced. Gary Stephen Maynard, 49, engaged in an arson spree in the Shasta Trinity National Forest and in the vicinity of the then-ongoing Dixie Fire in the Lassen National Forest, according to court documents. Maynard set some of his fires behind firefighters who were actively fighting the Dixie Fire, effectively surrounding these firefighters as they responded to the Dixie Fire. Maynard admitted to setting the following fires during this arson spree: the Cascade Fire (July 20, 2021), the Everitt Fire (July 21, 2021), the Ranch Fire (Aug. 7, 2021), and the Conard Fire (Aug. 7, 2021). This case is the product of an investigation by the U.S. Forest Service with assistance from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, CalFire, the California Highway Patrol, and the Lassen County Sheriff's Department. Assistant U.S. Attorneys Shea Kenny, Sam Stefanki, and Michael Anderson are prosecuting the case. Maynard is scheduled to be sentenced on May 9, 2024, by U.S. District Judge Daniel J. Calabretta. Maynard faces a maximum statutory penalty of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for each count to which he pleaded guilty.

author: abdulkareem.aldaham
title: Russia in weapon transfer talks with Yemen‚Äôs Houthis, says US envoy
text:
NEW YORK: The US has accused Russia of discussing weapon transfers with Houthis, whose attacks on Red Sea shipping are holding hostage a vital commercial waterway.
Speaking on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York, US Special Envoy for Yemen Tim Lenderking said Moscow was ‚Äúcutting its deals‚Äù with the Houthis to allow their ships to sail through the Red Sea unharmed.
‚ÄúWe have confirmation that the Russians and the Houthis are in dialogue about ways to cooperate,‚Äù including on weapon transfers, Lenderking said.
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know that weapons are being transferred as we speak, but it‚Äôs come to the point that we‚Äôre all sounding the alarm bell to ensure this does not happen,‚Äù he added.
If the weapon transfers were to materialize, it ‚Äúcould potentially change the conflict in a significant manner,‚Äù Lenderking said, warning of ‚Äúan escalation‚Äù that would derail already stalled efforts to end Yemen‚Äôs war.
‚ÄúThe notion that the Russians would provide the Houthis with lethal weapons is deeply alarming to the countries of the region,‚Äù he said.
Russia has been stepping up military relationships with Iran and North Korea, both under heavy sanctions, as it seeks to bolster its arsenal in its war in Ukraine.
Russia‚Äôs relationship with the US has deteriorated sharply since the invasion of Ukraine, with Washington leading the West in slapping sanctions on Moscow and arming Kyiv.
The Houthis have been firing drones and missiles at ships in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden since November, saying they are targeting vessels linked to Israel, the US, and Britain in a show of solidarity with Palestinians over the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.
The Houthi campaign has killed at least four sailors and sunk two ships.
One vessel ‚Äî the Galaxy Leader ‚Äî was hijacked in November and continues to be held by the Houthis along with its 25 international crew.

author: Spencer Holbrook
title: The top 10 quotes from postgame scene after Ohio State won national championship
text:
The top 10 quotes from postgame scene after Ohio State won national championship
ATLANTA ‚Äî Ohio State is the national champion of college football. The party is still ongoing ahead of the celebration inside the Horseshoe on Sunday.
And the postgame coverage is still nowhere near complete. With that in mind, Lettermen Row is putting together a list of 10 quotes, some funny, some sentimental, some serious and some just outrageous from the postgame celebrations on the field and inside the Mercedes-Benz Stadium locker room after a national title win.
Let‚Äôs break down the 10 best quotes Lettermen Row ‚Äî or other outlets ‚Äî heard as the confetti was settling Monday night.
10. Will Howard on what it means to win a national title for Buckeyes
Rex Kern, a 10th-round pick, was what the program needed under Woody Hayes in 1968 and won a national title. Flash forward to 2002, when Craig Krenzel, a fifth-round pick, helped the Buckeyes capture a title. Of course, everyone remembers Cardale Jones for his immaculate run through the four-team CFP. He became a fourth-round draft choice after winning his title in 2014.
Welcome to the club, Will Howard.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs humbling,‚Äù Howard said Tuesday morning after the Monday night game and celebration. ‚ÄúComing to Ohio State, obviously the expectation and the goal is in the end to win a National Championship. The fact that we‚Äôre sitting here today as national champions, it‚Äôs surreal, man. You‚Äôve got to really just take it in and thank God for the opportunity to be here and for the opportunity to be on this stage with these guys that I love. We‚Äôre going to be brothers for the rest of our lives because of this. We are bonded for life.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more than blood now, man. We‚Äôve got rings to show for it, and we‚Äôre going to be able to get together and tell this story of this team for years to come. I‚Äôm just so blessed that I was able to come here and be a part of something like this.‚Äù
9. Emeka Egbuka shares what he wants his legacy to be
Emeka Egbuka broke the Ohio State all-time receptions record during the national title game, passing K.J. Hill (2016-2019). Hill had 201. Egbuka ended his career with 205.
But he knows that record will be broken eventually, maybe even by Jeremiah Smith. So Lettermen Row wanted to know what his legacy is for the Buckeyes program.
‚ÄúI think my legacy here and what I want Buckeye fans and the whole state of Ohio to remember me for is how I glorify Jesus on the field,‚Äù Egbuka said. ‚ÄúThat was really my only goal. I tried to do that the best way I could. I came up short many, many times in my career. That can mean more to me than any record could.‚Äù
8. Buckeyes early-enrollee OL wants to meet LeBron
Lakers star and one of the best basketball players of all time LeBron James was in a suite for the game, watching his favorite college football team win a national title.
Some of the players hoped James would come down to the field and join the celebration after the game.
Early-enrollee offensive lineman Jayvon McFadden, a four-star recruit who signed with the program in December and will be on the team next season, asked one of his fellow early-enrollees: ‚ÄúWhere LeBron at?‚Äù
He left, Jayvon. Maybe you‚Äôll get to meet him eventually, but it wasn‚Äôt going to be after this title game win.
7. Ryan Day loves Ohio State
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an honor to be the head coach at Ohio State,‚Äù he said Tuesday morning. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd probably say that this job is not for everybody, and every year I‚Äôve learned more about myself than I thought going into the season. A big part of it is these players, and I shared that with the guys this season.
‚ÄúI felt like we were knocking on the door several times leading up to this game. You think about the ‚Äô19 team, you think about the ‚Äô20 team. Every year I felt like we were close, but we just couldn‚Äôt get through. This team was different. This team was special. The message was to leave no doubt. Don‚Äôt leave it to one play, don‚Äôt leave it to one call and don‚Äôt leave it in the hands of somebody else. Don‚Äôt do that.
‚ÄúI felt like the throw-and-catch there to Jeremiah at the end was like, okay, we‚Äôre leaving no doubt with this thing.
‚ÄúTo answer your question about the other part of it, I don‚Äôt know. I just know that Ohio State is a special place. It‚Äôs an honor to be here, an honor to be around some of those names that you just said, because when you hear some of those names like that, they‚Äôre some of the best coaches in the history of the game.
‚ÄúBut the only way you do that is with great players and great people, and obviously this is a great place.‚Äù
6. Was there any doubt who the ball was going to on third and 11? From College Sports on Sirius XM
College Sports on Sirius XM asked this to Ryan Day and Jeremiah Smith after the game‚Ä¶
Ryan Day: ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù
Jeremiah Smith: ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù
Smith: ‚ÄúI love coach Day to death. I‚Äôd do anything for him. Just happy to be on his team and being a Buckeye.‚Äù
Senior receiver Emeka Egbuka added in the postgame locker room scene: ‚Äú‚ÄùThe only thing that‚Äôs freshman about Jeremiah is his age.‚Äù
In his postgame press conference, Day was asked about why the Buckeyes decided to call that deep shot to Smith with the game on the line‚Ä¶
‚ÄúWe felt like we had an advantage with Jeremiah on that shot, and we talked about it all week. We really hadn‚Äôt thrown one all game, and it was like, you know what, game on the line, let‚Äôs just go. Let‚Äôs go aggressive.
Get the On3 Top 10 to your inbox every morning
By clicking "Subscribe to Newsletter", I agree to On3's Privacy Notice, Terms, and use of my personal information described therein.
‚ÄúI just thought to myself, only one National Championship, you only get one opportunity a year to do this, let‚Äôs just lay it on the line and put it out there and be aggressive. And that‚Äôs what we did.
‚ÄúI talked to the defensive guys and I talked to the offensive guys that we were going to continue to be aggressive throughout the game. I told the team that leading up to the game. And I had to make sure I followed through that.‚Äù
Boy, did they. The deep ball now known as ‚Äúthird and Jeremiah‚Äù will live in Ohio State lore.
5. Ryan Day reflects on the change from regular season loss to postseason dominance
‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say that it was a reset. It wasn‚Äôt like at the end of the year we were broken. It wasn‚Äôt that way. We had an awful day. I don‚Äôt know how else to describe it. We had an awful day, and we just said we could never do that again.
‚ÄúAnd I think it‚Äôs the job of the head coach to take the responsibility when something goes bad like that, but then on days like this, make sure that everyone understands it‚Äôs the warriors and guys on the field that deserve all the credit, not the coach. The coach gets too much attention sometimes. I want to make sure these guys are the ones getting the attention.‚Äù
4. Carson Hinzman gives hilarious quote to Lettermen Row while puffing cigar
Hinzman replaced an injured Seth McLaughlin in November after starting 12 games as an undersized center in 2023. Now he‚Äôs the national title-winning center who replaced the Rimington Trophy-winning center. What a remarkable story for Hinzman, who will be one of the unquestioned leaders of the offensive line next year.
The Wisconsin native who grew up on a dairy farm reflected on his journey.
‚ÄúThe resilience that God has bestowed in me is unquestionable. I think coming from my family and where I‚Äôve been from, and what these guys have done for me, Coach Mick and what the coaches have done, I think I‚Äôve been more than ready to take over the lead. I‚Äôm not Seth. I‚Äôm nowhere near trying to fill his shoes, but I‚Äôm trying to be me and do everything I can to try getting better every day. ‚Ä¶
‚ÄúWisconsin cream rises to the top, and that‚Äôs what happened here.‚Äù
3. Josh Fryar, Donovan Jackson tell Kings of the North their postgame plans
The best quote from the entire postgame celebration came from friends of Lettermen Row, Kings of the North. While Bill Landis was live on the field after the game, he asked Josh Fryar and Donovan Jackson about their postgame plans.
The responses from both were epic.
Fryar: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting hammered.‚Äù
Jackson: ‚ÄúI will be right there with him getting hammered. I am 22 years old, and I can legally do it.‚Äù
2. Jack Sawyer answers what it means to know Ryan Day is a national title-winning coach
Lettermen Row then asked the senior leader, star defensive end, Central Ohio native and avid Ryan Day defender what he thinks knowing Day is a national champion:
‚ÄúDamn right he is. He‚Äôs the best coach in college football. And he‚Äôs going to win a couple more of these things here soon.‚Äù
1. Ryan Day speaks about his national title-winning roster
‚ÄúI think this playoff system allowed our team to grow and learn and build. You can say whatever you want about people talked a lot about how much money guys were making in NIL and different things like that. That was just because NIL was available. The majority of our team came back. These guys have been here for a long time.
‚ÄúCertainly Will was a huge addition, Caleb was a huge addition, don‚Äôt get me wrong. But when you hear that number, that doesn‚Äôt mean a whole lot other than the fact that the market value for our guys in Columbus at Ohio State is pretty high. That‚Äôs what it means. When that got tagged on us early, there was a lot of pressure put on our players.
‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs nothing new at Ohio State. I think the difference is that we finished the season the right way, and we grew. We built, and we responded to tough times. Man, isn‚Äôt that what life is all about.
‚ÄúThese guys learned a bunch of life lessons, but they‚Äôre going to go down in Ohio State history as one of the greatest teams to ever play at Ohio State. After all the things that have been said throughout the year, these guys are going to be cemented as one of the best stories in Ohio State history and one of the best football teams ever. Only nine teams have ever done it, and three in over 50 years. These guys right here. There was a point where not a lot of people had that vision, but these guys did, and they saw it through.
‚ÄúOhio State may not be for everybody, but it‚Äôs for these guys, and I‚Äôm really proud of them.‚Äù
Bonus 1: Ryan Day embraces family
Credit 10TV‚Äôs Adam King and his videographer for capturing this moment that absolutely cannot be left off the list.
Ryan‚Äôs wife Nina: ‚ÄúOh my God, you did it!‚Äù
Ryan Day, hugging Nina and his family: ‚ÄúWe did it. We did it. We did it.‚Äù
Day‚Äôs son, RJ: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre so proud of you, dad.‚Äù

author: Tyler Layne
title: Caller says he was put on hold for 10 minutes after calling Richmond 911
text:
1 weather alerts 1 closings/delays Watch Now Watch Now 1 weather alerts 1 closings/delays Menu

News Local Your Voice, Your Story National Politics Virginia Politics Entertainment Offbeat Sports Weather 1 weather alerts 1 closings/delays
Local News Actions Facebook Tweet Email Caller in emergency says he was put on hold for 10 minutes after calling Richmond 911: 'Real disappointing' Prev Next By: Tyler Layne Posted RICHMOND, Va. ‚Äî With his car broken down on the shoulder of Chippenham Parkway with trucks and other vehicles zooming by, Pouncee Nelson was in need of help. On Jan. 10, at the advice of roadside assistance from AAA, he called Richmond 911 to see if officers could respond and put out flare flights.
But he said no one answered.
‚ÄúIt went to a recording. It said, ‚Äòstay on the line, all operators are busy,‚Äô and I stayed on the phone for 10 minutes. No one ever came to the line," Nelson recalled.
He then hung up the phone and called Virginia State Police, but before the agency was able to get an officer on the scene, a tow truck had arrived to bring him to safety.
‚ÄúIt was a real disappointing, disappointing evening that that happened, and like I said, we could have been killed," Nelson said. "I just hate to think of a situation if someone had been having a heart attack or accident, where you really needed that medical attention immediately to save your life, and you dial 911 and this is what you get.‚Äù
Taylor Fuqua, a spokesperson for Richmond's Department of Emergency Communications (DEC), said DEC received 19 911 calls during the timeframe of Nelson's call, and several of them were for "serious incidents."
For seven of those calls, Fuqua said it took more than two minutes for an operator to answer.
Nelson's experience is not unique. City Councilmember Sarah Abubaker shared with CBS 6 a recording of an automated message that she said one of her constituents received after calling 911.
The message said in part, ‚Äú You have reached the Richmond 911 Emergency Call Center. You have not been placed on hold or sent to voicemail. We are experiencing a high volume of emergency calls at this time.‚Äù
Abubker played that same recording at a public safety committee meeting in March after DEC Director Stephen Willoughby claimed that callers "never" get sent to voicemail ‚Äî a remark that Abubaker dismissed as "semantics."
‚ÄúThey say it‚Äôs not voicemail, but it‚Äôs an automated response and they‚Äôre still being putting on hold. You can call a rose by any other name. It is voicemail," she said.
During that meeting, Ryan Clarke, who said he works at Richmond 911 and is a member of a union, said operators are stretched thin right now, partly due to a change that took effect in July of last year that required DEC to take control over medical calls ‚Äî something that used to be handled by the Richmond Ambulance Authority (RAA).
Clarke called it a "huge change" that staff were not properly trained for.
‚ÄúOur members, they feel overwhelmed, they feel unprepared, they feel stressed out going to work. That‚Äôs all kind of leading to a level of service that‚Äôs impacting the citizens of the city, and it‚Äôs not as good as we could be," Clarke said. "This change has added to an already overwhelmed workload for 911 call takers who already face understaffing and increased responsibilities."
Before July 2024, DEC would transfer medical emergency calls, such as reports of heart attacks and cardiac arrests, to RAA so that its staff could triage the calls and determine what types of response and services were appropriate. But not even a year after the change was implemented, RAA wants to take that responsibility back.
RAA CEO Chip Decker told councilmembers that the authority's personnel have the more appropriate medical background to properly assess and prioritize medical emergency calls. He said errors in categorizing these kinds of calls have only increased under DEC's management, which in turn impacts RAA's response times.
Between July and December 2023, Decker said there were 85 reported "upgrades," which meant first responders arrived on scene of an emergency to find the patient's condition was more serious than initially categorized. Between July and December 2024, after DEC began fielding medical calls, RAA reported 209 "upgrades."
"I need DEC to get it right. They have to answer the phone, they have to pick the right event type, then they have to follow it down to the right determinant," Decker said.
Meanwhile, DEC argued that the switch helped save time by eliminating the step of transferring medical calls to another agency. DEC officials said there's been a one-minute reduction in how long it takes to code a call, meaning pre-arrival instructions have been able to begin sooner for people in crisis. Eliminating transfers also reduced the risks of calls being dropped, they said.
Additionally, by centralizing resources, DEC Deputy Director Jackie Crotts said citizens no longer have to talk to multiple communications officer which will "reduce frustration" for callers.
"EMTs and paramedics taking 911 calls is an antiquated way of doing business and delivering service. For instance, police officers and firefighters haven't answered 911 calls or emergency calls in the City of Richmond in 30 years," Willoughby said.
When Abubaker asked for data about how many callers receive the automated message and how many calls have been categorized incorrectly, Willoughby did not have that information.
Fuqua told CBS 6 that the average percentage of callers who hang up before an operator can answer is 6% so far this year. It was 13.5% in all of 2024.
Councilmembers said they're requesting more data before making a decision on how to move forward regarding the management of medical emergency calls. Following the public safety meeting, Stephanie Lynch said she was left with a "question mark" as to whether the city made the right move back in July.
In a statement to CBS 6, Abubaker said, "For years, RAA played a central role in answering medical 911 calls ‚Äî a system that, by many accounts, worked well. It's unclear why we would move away from something that was reliably serving the public... If returning to the previous model results in faster, more accurate responses and better patient care, then that's the direction we should move in. This isn't about turf -- it's about getting results for the people we serve."
CBS 6 is committed to sharing community voices on this important topic. Email your thoughts to the CBS 6 Newsroom .

author: Karina Hollingsworth
title: chevron-right
text: MERKEL, Tx ‚Äî According to Merkel residents the roads are a hassle to travel, on even the sunniest day. But when it rains it pours, and the Merkel roads can‚Äôt handle the overflow. Anna Maria Salinas says potholes and flooding is a huge issue in Merkel. ‚ÄúWe have problems when it rains,‚Äù Salinas said. ‚ÄúWe ask if we can have gravel and dirt. Sometimes they come and they put some down. But when it rains there is always a hole. It‚Äôs everywhere you go, and I wish they would fix the roads.‚Äù According to Salinas the water rises extremely fast on Yucca St., but in her opinion the worst flooding occurs where the children play. ‚ÄúIt always gets so bad,‚Äù Salinas said. Mainly up by the schools.‚Äù The three-year Merkel resident only wants what‚Äôs best for Merkel, and its residents. ‚ÄúI wish they would fix them so we can have good roads where they won‚Äôt be so bumpy,‚Äù Salinas said. ‚ÄúI know the elderly likes to go walking and there is always holes everywhere. They get hurt. That‚Äôs what I would like, for the residents in this little town to have a safe place to walk.‚Äù Merkel‚Äôs city manager Brian Weaver says Merkel is working on a budget to repair the roads. The city manager said addressing the flooding problem is going to be a more difficult problem to solve but they are searching for funds to find a solution.

author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text:
During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle.
The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription ‚ÄúMay this keep you safe from harm."
Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France.
His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back.
Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarch‚Äôs belongings.
On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war.
‚ÄòI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages‚Äô Coogan‚Äôs uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.‚Äù
Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums.
‚ÄúThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,‚Äù Coogan told USA TODAY. ‚ÄúThey would put it in their coat pockets ‚Ä¶ like the front breast pocket ‚Ä¶ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.‚Äù
Lt. McKnight‚Äôs name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldn‚Äôt put it down, she recalled.
‚ÄúI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,‚Äù she said.
She noticed that the Bible‚Äôs front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out.
Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bible‚Äôs cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bible‚Äôs safe return to an address not too far away.
Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called.
‚ÄúI was just hoping for the best,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúWe found out that number worked.‚Äù
A car wreck took her 3 kids. Now through surrogacy, she is a mom again to a baby boy. A Georgia family was about to lose insurance for teen's cancer battle. Then they got help. Pedaling kindness: Massachusetts Peloton group leaves servers $7,200 tip 'Feed somebody you don‚Äôt know': Philadelphia man inspires, heals through food Why strangers raised $450,000 to help a dependable Burger King worker buy his first home Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York.
Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Force‚Äôs 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, online records show.
Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fay‚Äôs husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life.
‚ÄúHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,‚Äù Coogan said.
Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost.
‚ÄúHe didn't lose it,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale ‚Ä¶ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.‚Äù
It ended up in Coogan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said.
‚ÄúThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,‚Äù she said.

author: VNExplorer
title: ¬´ Un sentiment d‚Äôimpunit√© total ¬ª : Depardieu, Abril‚Ä¶ Lucie Lucas d√©nonce le comportement de certains acteurs
text:
¬´ √É∆í√¢‚Ç¨¬°a fait 15 ans que je suis com√É∆í√Ç¬©dienne et que je prot√É∆í√Ç¬®ge une bonne partie de ces boomers d√É∆í√Ç¬©g√É∆í√Ç¬©n√É∆í√Ç¬©r√É∆í√Ç¬©s en ne disant pas en interview tout le mal qu√É¬¢√¢‚Äö¬¨√¢‚Äû¬¢ils font aux autres sur un plateau de tournage √É‚Äö√Ç¬ª, a affirm√É∆í√Ç¬© Lucie Lucas dans un commentaire sur Instagram. LP/Fred Dugit
Sa r√©action √† l‚Äôaffaire G√©rard Depardieu avait fait beaucoup parler, Lucie Lucas a d√©cid√© de sortir du silence. Jeudi, l‚Äôactrice s‚Äôest exprim√©e au micro de franceinfo au sujet de la tribune sign√©e par une cinquantaine d‚Äôartistes en soutien √† l‚Äôacteur, mis en examen pour viols et accus√© par de nombreuses femmes d‚Äôagressions sexuelles. Elle est √©galement revenue sur ses √©crits visant l‚Äôactrice Victoria Abril, signataire du texte, avec qui elle a beaucoup tourn√©.
Tout commence mardi sur Instagram. La com√©dienne Charlotte Arnould, l‚Äôune des accusatrices de G√©rard Depardieu, publie sur le r√©seau social la liste des signataires de la tribune en soutien √† l‚Äôacteur. Dans les commentaires, Lucie Lucas s‚Äôemporte.
¬´ Tu veux qu‚Äôon parle de tes nombreuses agressions y compris sexuelles envers tes partenaires ? ¬ª ¬´√É‚Äö√Ç √É∆í√¢‚Ç¨¬°a fait 15 ans que je suis com√É∆í√Ç¬©dienne et que je prot√É∆í√Ç¬®ge une bonne partie de ces boomers d√É∆í√Ç¬©g√É∆í√Ç¬©n√É∆í√Ç¬©r√É∆í√Ç¬©s en ne disant pas en interview tout le mal qu√É¬¢√¢‚Äö¬¨√¢‚Äû¬¢ils font aux autres sur un plateau de tournage (√É¬¢√¢‚Äö¬¨√Ç¬¶) J√É¬¢√¢‚Äö¬¨√¢‚Äû¬¢ai beaucoup √É∆í√Ç dire sur certaines personnes de cette liste d√É∆í√Ç¬©licieuse de cosignataires√É‚Äö√Ç √É‚Äö√Ç¬ª, √É∆í√Ç¬©crit-elle. Avant de s√É¬¢√¢‚Äö¬¨√¢‚Äû¬¢en prendre directement √É∆í√Ç Victoria Abril, qui joue le r√É∆í√Ç¬¥le de sa m√É∆í√Ç¬®re dans la s√É∆í√Ç¬©rie Clem√Ç : √Ç¬´√Ç Tu veux qu√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢on parle de tes nombreuses agressions y compris sexuelles envers tes partenaires√Ç ? √É‚Ç¨ y r√É¬©fl√É¬©chir, je ne suis pas surprise que tu aies sign√É¬© ce torchon√¢‚Ç¨¬¶ Tu flippes toi aussi et √É y r√É¬©fl√É¬©chir tu as bien raison√Ç √Ç¬ª.
Jeudi, au micro de Franceinfo, Lucie Lucas a pr√©cis√© ses d√©clarations sur sa cons≈ìur. ¬´ Les violences sexuelles dont je l‚Äôaccuse n‚Äôont pas √©t√© tourn√©es contre moi, mais ce sont des choses dont j‚Äôai √©t√© t√©moin, explique l‚Äôactrice. Ce n‚Äôest pas Victoria Abril que j‚Äôai envie d‚Äôaccuser. J‚Äôai eu cette esp√®ce de mont√©e de sang. Je me suis peut-√™tre permis √ßa, car c‚Äôest ma maman du cin√©ma et je me suis sentie profond√©ment trahie et abandonn√©e ¬ª.
¬´ Tyranniser des plateaux entiers ¬ª Plus qu‚Äôun acteur ou une actrice en particulier, Lucie Lucas cible une g√©n√©ration de com√©diens. ¬´ Ce que je voudrais d√©noncer, c‚Äôest qu‚Äôil y a une impunit√©, un sentiment d‚Äôimpunit√© qui est total chez certaines personnes et notamment chez certaines personnes des g√©n√©rations de G√©rard Depardieu et Victoria Abril, qui se permettent de tyranniser des plateaux entiers et d‚Äôavoir des comportements que je ne trouve pas admissibles voire qui ne sont pas l√©gaux ¬ª.
Victoria Abril n‚Äôa, pour le moment, pas comment√© les d√©clarations de Lucie Lucas. Mais l‚Äôacteur Kevin Elarbi, qui a jou√© aux c√¥t√©s des deux actrices dans la s√©rie Clem, a pris sa d√©fense sur X (ex-Twitter) : ¬´ Victoria Abril est int√®gre, et a sa libert√© d‚Äôexpression. Qu‚Äôon soit d‚Äôaccord ou non, elle a le droit de parole. Sans dictature fasciste de la censure. Je le lui ai dit hier, qu‚Äôelle soit assur√©e de mon soutien inconditionnel. Travailler avec elle sur Clem fut un honneur ¬ª.

author: admin_l6ma5gus
title: Granada floor waitresses are planted against the employer for their labor rights: "Without us there is no hotel"
text:
Granada floor waitresses have said enough. His reality is drawn exhausting as his stories are known, such as Bel√©n Casta√±eda. At 54, he is 17 as a flat waitress in hotels in the city of the Alhambra. His body no longer endures the rhythm, being in charge of two children and a dependent husband in a high degree, but stands. ‚ÄúI have osteoarthritis, lumbar problems, shattered dolls and yet I have to continue working because there is no other option,‚Äù he explains.
The cry of the ‚Äòkellys‚Äô and summer waitresses through literature: ‚ÄúAny resistance exercise‚Äù
During his career he has seen how working conditions have worsened: outsourcing of services, more rooms per day -calling 2 euros per room -less salary and less rights. ‚ÄúBefore we had eight hours to do our homework, now we have to clean rooms in less than 20 minutes. And if the client leaves the room at 12, at 12:30 there is already another waiting,‚Äù says this worker.
Day after day, Bethlehem and many others are forced to assume ‚Äústrenuous‚Äù working conditions, which go through eternal days, low wages and injuries that are not always enough to be low or, worse, that can be withdrawn because some are disabling. Tired of the disdain with which they are treated from the hotels in which they work cleaning and fixing the rooms and stays, they have been planted before the employer to claim measures that reverse their situation. They will do it first from Granada, but they aspire to make their wick pledge throughout Spain.
While the employer defends that the situation ‚Äúis not so serious‚Äù, the Government opens to assess that certain professions, among which the floor waitresses would be, can retire before they turn 67 without being penalized. To achieve their objectives and gathered in the Assembly, they have launched a manifesto in which they denounce the conditions of exploitation in the sector: low wages, precarious contracts, abusive work rhythms and physical wear that leaves them with sequelae before reaching the retirement age.
Central manifestation in Granada
He knows well what he‚Äôs talking about, since Bel√©n has gone through several hotels and in all he has found the same pattern: ‚ÄúThey see us as invisible. In hotels, the face is given and the waiters, but without us, there is no hotel.‚Äù Despite the difficulties, he has always fought against precariousness, denouncing hidden before the Labor Inspection, which has made him suffer reprisals. ‚ÄúIf you complain, they put you in the blacklist. But you have to report because this work is killing us.‚Äù
They demand, among other measures, early retirement without penalty in the pensions they receive for withdrawing before stipulated by law, compliance with the hospitality agreement, the end of outsourcing and guarantee that their rest days are respected. They point out that while hotels increase their benefits, they continue to suffer unassumable workloads that seriously affect their health.
To make visible their fight, they have joined in the Trade Union Coordination of Workers of Andalusia (CSTA) And they have summoned mobilizations, with a central demonstration in Granada on May 31, in addition to previous concentrations in different parts of the province. ‚ÄúThey are squeezing us and, if we don‚Äôt go out, nobody listens to us,‚Äù they say. The next April 10 will be planted before the headquarters of the hospitality employer of Granada to warn them that this will be the first of many actions that will not stop until their reality improves.
Exhausted and exhausted
To√±i Milla also has 54 years and three decades of experience in the sector. Every morning, before leaving home, you must take a drug cocktail to relieve the pain of your hands, affected by the breakage of the carpal tunnel in both and osteoarthritis. ‚ÄúI get up with my hands asleep, fans. I find it hard to start, but you have to continue,‚Äù he says. In their experience, few reach the retirement age without having passed before disabling diseases. ‚ÄúOnly 5% of the waiters of floor in Spain arrive at 65. We retire before, but because of illness,‚Äù he denounces.
Working conditions have changed dramatically since it started working. ‚ÄúBefore we were hired by the hotel, now everything is managed by external companies. We have lowered the hours of contract and have uploaded the number of rooms,‚Äù he explains. Today, some workers have to clean up to 16 or 17 rooms in a four -hour day, which forces them to stay longer without being paid for it. ‚ÄúThey are squeezing us. And if we protect, they tell us that we are not going to get anything. Well, staying at home we do not get anything,‚Äù he says.
Precariousness is not just the veteran thing. Valentina √Ålvarez is 27 years old and already drags chronic back pain. He has been working in hotels for almost a decade and has seen how the trend is to hire young women, many of them migrants, hoping that they will end up without complaining. ‚ÄúI thought it was strong, but I‚Äôve been at this hotel only and I already have back pain that doesn‚Äôt take me away,‚Äù he says. In their company, workers clean the bathrooms One of her companions is low because, literally, she could not stand up after a working day.
In recent years, he has seen dozens of companions through the hotel. ‚ÄúThey hire young women or with family charges because they know they are not going to complain. We change the shifts without prior notice, they raise the workload and if we protect, they tell us that we are young and that we should not complain.‚Äù For her, the fight is essential: ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt fight, nothing will change. They treat us as if we were machines, but we are people. Nobody can endure this rhythm up to 67 years.‚Äù
The employer denies precariousness
From the Federation of Hospitality of Granada, its general secretary, Juanma L√≥pez, denies that the situation is so serious. ‚ÄúIt is not good to generalize,‚Äù he says. Defends that ‚Äúcompanies scrupulously comply with the collective agreement‚Äù and that ‚Äúthe workload is reasonable.‚Äù It also argues that ‚Äúthe business benefit should not be correlated with the discomfort of workers‚Äù because ‚Äúwages and conditions are regulated by collective bargaining.‚Äù
L√≥pez insists that all hospitality cannot be responsible for the bad practices of some companies since there are hotels where the conditions are good. However, it acknowledges that there are establishments where the outsourcing precarizes the conditions, although it defends that, in any case, the hospitality agreement must be fulfilled. It also values ‚Äã‚Äãthe effort of the employer in the last agreement for matching the conditions of the floor waitresses with those of other workers in the sector, such as receptionists and room waiters.
Despite this, the workers do not see significant improvements in their day to day. The difference between what the employers‚Äô and the reality of floor waitresses says is evident: while some talk about compliance with the agreement, others tell how work rhythms are destroying them. The struggle for early retirement without penalty in pensions is only part of a major problem: to be able to work without its health deteriorating irreversibly. ‚ÄúIt is impossible to reach 67 years in this work. We do not arrive. And those who do it, are broken,‚Äù says To√±i Milla.
The Government values ‚Äã‚Äãearly retirements
However, for some time, the central government values ‚Äã‚Äãthe possibility that floor waitresses can retire in advance without suffering penalties in their pensions. ‚ÄúOur own patterns recognize us that they prefer it because we cost them money being low and if we are usually injured, they have to hire more people,‚Äù Valentina explains. However, he emphasizes that they would suffer so many casualties ‚Äúif they gave good conditions.‚Äù
Rafaela and Mar have the ‚Äúbroken body‚Äù of cleaning and will fight to be recognized: ‚ÄúWe live with pain‚Äù
From the Ministries of Social Security and Labor this issue has been addressed, although without concrete advances. In the first one a negotiating table with the unions is kept open to assess this possibility and in the case of the second, its headline, Yolanda D√≠az, assumes that the penalties must be ‚Äúcorrected‚Äù in certain professions in which ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt do more‚Äù When an advanced age is reached.
Through our Instagram account we move what happens in Andalusia and Seville beyond words: we inform you of the latest news and we offer you extra content so that you know reality in detail.
Go to our community in This link .
